title: found a bill that i forgot to pay from back in 2014.
question: found a bill that i forgot to pay from back in 2014. It wasn't a large bill, around $1500. I tried to contact the company, but found that they had gone bankrupt. I was able to find the company that bought them out. I contacted them and they referred me to one of their lawyers. He told me tosend them a check for the total amount, which i am ok with doing. What I'm concerned about is will this be the end of it? Is it possible for them to try and sue me, or continue to charge me after i pay? I took on the debt while i was living in Kansas, I currently live in California. The company is located in Illinois.
question_tags: Business contracts,Bankruptcy,Debt,Debt settlement,Debt negotiation,Bankruptcy and debt
answers:
Unless the debt appears on your credit reports OR you were contacted by the current creditor or a debt collector, it is probably not a good idea to pay this debt. As others have mentioned, there is a statute of limitations that applies to the collection of a debt. The debt incurred in 2014 may be "time-barred" which means that it is too old to be collected through a lawsuit. If the statute of limitations is 5 years, it is probably time-barred. And, if the debt is more than 7 years old, and there has been no payment at all during that time, is is also too old to be reported on your credit reports.

The main reason to avoid making a time-barred debt is that you could be reviving the statute of limitations that applies to the entire debt, which may include interest, late fees, etc. Worst-case-scenario: you pay the $1,500, the statute of limitations is re-started, the creditor decides that it will attempt to extract more money from you, and may begin to report the debt to credit reporting agencies as delinquent. Best-case-scenario: you pay the $1,500 and never hear from anyone again (which is fine, but you'd have $1,500 less to spend on other things you need).
Don't you recall hearing something about sleeping dogs and letting them lay.. from the facts presented, I don't think that you have any legal obligation to pay this bill.

It appears the debt is beyond the Statute of Limitations and therefore, uncollectible. Whatever you do, don't send them any money because that revives the debt and allows the creditor a new 4 year period to sue you. If you filed BK and forgot to list the debt, it is discharged if your case was a non-asset case under IN RE BEEZLEY (1992)
No. 91-55809. 994 F.2d 1433 (1993). If you did not file BK, but the creditor did, the money you owed was an asset in that case. You probably need the $1500 more than a collection agency who paid noting or pennies on the dollar to buy the debt. You are to be commended for your personal integrity for recognizing your moral obligation to pay a legally uncollectible debt.

I would speak to an attorney before you make any payment. You could be restarting the statute of limitation and the $1,500.00 is the amount from 2014. You may have interest that have accrued, and when you make your payment, there is now a balance that is unpaid due to interest. If you want to pay it, it's best to get everything in writing that your payment will satisfy the debt in full.

OR it could be Illinois law or any other state that the contract lists.
It's nice that you want to pay. It's more likely than not that you do not
have to. The bankruptcy trustee should have been in touch with you
about your bill being an asset to the company. It is almost certainly not
owed any longer and can even be negotiated down OR not paid. I know
that is a LOT to digest. I'm changing the topic to BK law to help you get
better responses...

Under KS law, the creditor had 5 years from your date of breach (that's the date of your last payment made, or the payment due date) to sue you for breach of a written contract, if that's what this was, plus interest and the non-breaching party's legal fees, if those things were provided in the written contract.

So maybe you have a MORAL obligation, but you have no LEGAL obligation to pay them anything.

And this is the successor company. The bankrupt company likely got a discharge in bankruptcy court for your debt, along with their other receivables, and the purchasing company bought the company in bankruptcy subject to that discharge. More reason not to pay anyone anything.

So if you want to pay this successor company, go ahead, but if they don't know your name or your address, they'd have a hard time claiming you resurrected the statute of limitations and re-started the 5 years. Unless of course you DID do exactly that and admitted you owed their predecessor money and you DID give them your contact information. If you insist on paying, make sure you get a written release that says: 1) this successor company owns the debt to ____[original company] 2) the agree your payment is in full and final settlement of any obligation you owe to ___ ___, and they agree to release you with prejudice.

The contract may be governed by Kansas law. You’re emailing California attorneys. But it is very possible they are beyond the statute to sue. Discuss the contract and facts with a Kansas attorney. But either way you can still pay them if you want to pay your debts.
